College of Chemistry Sichuan University Wang jiang Road 29 Chengdu Sichuan 610064 PR China The formation of new pollutants NH3 and N2O during the conversion of nitrogen oxides by three-way catalysts (TWC) has a significant impact on the environment and human health, so it is necessary to understand their formation pathways. The redox performance of the support and the surface active oxygen species affect the catalytic reaction performance and selectivity. In this work, the effect of CeO2 (Ce) and γ-Al2O3 (La-Al2O3, LA), the two kinds of widely used supports for Pt-based TWC on the formation pathways of NH3 and N2O was investigated due to the different support redox properties and surface reactive oxygen species affecting the reactant reaction properties. NH3 and N2O are formed by the reaction of oxygen activated CH4 or CO with NO, respectively. The cumulative formation concentration of NH3 and N2O over Pt/Ce are about 1.7 and 0.24 times more than that of Pt/LA, about 16,498 and 5059 ppm, respectively. The Pt/Ce catalyst has strong redox properties and high extractable oxygen content. At high temperatures, it promotes the formation of NCO* from the reduction of NO by oxygen-activated CH4, which in turn hydrolyzes to form a large amount of NH3. At low temperatures, it preferentially activates the reaction between CO with H2O and O2, which leads to a weaker competition for the reduction of NO by CO, which in turn leads to the formation of a smaller amount of N2O. This study provides new ideas for the formation mechanism of NH3 and N2O in stoichiometric natural gas vehicles (NGVs). Graphical abstracts Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3 N2O redox properties Extractable oxygen NCO* Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Natural gas vehicles (NGVs) have been rapidly and widely promoted in the transportation sector as an alternative to conventional fuel vehicles[1]. In order to meet increasingly stringent emission regulations, NGVs must use three-way catalysts (TWC) to efficiently convert exhaust gasses containing pollutant emissions such as CH4, NOx, and CO into nontoxic CO2, N2, and H2O, respectively. However, when converting NOx to form new pollutants NH3 and N2O will not only affect the environment, but also have a greater impact on human health. In a study conducted by Heeb[2] and colleagues, it was shown that NH3 and N2O emissions before TWC were less than 5 mg/km, whereas NH3 and N2O emissions after TWC could reach 20–75 mg/km. The implementation of China VI emission standards explicitly require an emission limit of 10 ppm or less for NH3, future emission standards will further limit N2O emissions. Therefore, there is an urgent need to design TWC that can reduce the formation of NH3 and N2O from NGVs. In response to the above, it is necessary to understand the formation pathways of NH3 and N2O. Given the need for further elimination of these pollutants, a significant amount of recent research efforts has focused on inhibiting their formation. These efforts have resulted in a number of proposals for the formation mechanism schemes, in which the most widely accepted routes for NH3 formation are the hydrolysis of isocyanate (NCO*) and the water gas shift (WGS)/NOx hydrogenation. In the first pathway, the formation of NCO* is sharply influenced by the composition of the reaction components. Yoo [3] et al. found that NO/CO ratio is a factor influencing the formation of NCO*. The N* dissociated from NO reacts competitively with CO and NO, and the reaction of N* with CO forms NCO*, which is further hydrolyzed to NH3. Thus higher NO/CO ratios inhibit the formation of NCO*, leading to a lower formation rate and selectivity of NH3. In addition, Amiridis et al. [4] found that partially oxidized hydrocarbons can likewise react with NO to form NCO*. The WGS/NOx hydrogenation pathway involves the formation of H2 from CO+H2O, which is a good reducing agent for NO to reduce it to NH3[5-10]. For N2O, several different formation pathways have also been reported, including the incomplete reduction of NO by H2, CO or HC[11,12], the desorption of N* and O* stemming from decomposition of NO in the form of N2 and N2O[13], and the reaction among cyanide (-CN) with NO, NO2 and O2, in which the -CN comes from the reaction between oxygen-activated hydrocarbon derivatives and NO[14]. It should be noted that the above mechanisms relate only to the effects of individual reductants consisting of simulated exhaust on NH3 and N2O emissions. In addition, autoxidation of NO can likewise form N2O according to Ren et al.[15-17]. However, the reactions carried out on the catalysts for the tail gas treatment of stoichiometric natural gas engines, which are interdependent and interrelated, and the mechanism for the formation of NH3 and N2O when both CH4 NOCOH2OO2 components are present is not clear. Moreover, the effects of related factors for the formation of NH3 and N2O, like the catalyst composition, reaction temperature and variable supports have not been reported, which is highly desirable and urgently necessary to be studied. CeO2 (Ce) and La-loaded γ-Al2O3 (La-Al2O3, LA) are two kinds of the most well-known and widely used support for TWC. Pd-Rh-based TWC have been widely studied due to their excellent catalytic properties. However, the increase in the price of Pd and Rh in recent years has hindered the application of Pd-Rh TWC, and the price of Pt is lower and more stable than that of Pd and Rh[18]. Huo et al. [19]. conducted experiments with different PGM ratios to investigate the effect of PGM ratios on the performance of TWCs and found that increasing the Pt content improves the CH4 and NOx conversion efficiencies, but has less effect on CO emissions. Hu et al. [20]. discovered Pt/Rh synergy in Pt-Rh triple effect catalysts. Compared with monometallic catalysts, bimetallic or trimetallic catalysts have higher catalytic activity and stability. In our work, Pt/Ce and Pt/LA catalysts were synthesized and the differences in the pathways through which redox and non-redox supports affect the formation of NH3 and N2O were investigated using reactions between different component gasses and in situ DRIFTS. NCO*, an intermediate species formed by the reaction of oxygen-activated CH4 with NO, hydrolyzes to form NH3. N2O is formed by the reduction of NO by CO. The Pt/Ce catalyst has strong redox properties and high extractable oxygen content. At high temperatures, it promotes the formation of NCO* from the reduction of NO by oxygen-activated CH4, which in turn hydrolyzes to form a large amount of NH3. At low temperatures, it preferentially activates the reaction between CO with H2O and O2, which leads to a weaker competition for the reduction of NO by CO, which in turn leads to the formation of a smaller amount of N2O. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Pt(NO3)2 was impregnated onto different supports (CeO2 and La-Al2O3) with a Pt loading of 1.5 wt.%. Then the as prepared powders were dried overnight and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h to obtain Pt/CeO2 and Pt/La-Al2O3, respectively. In order to evaluate the catalytic activity of the samples, the catalysts powders and the binders were balled milled into slurry to be coated onto the surface of cordierite. In detail, the cordierite was immersed vertically in the slurry for 2 min. Excess slurry was removed using a stream of compressed air, and the coating volume was controlled at 120±2 g/ft3. This process was repeated three times and three sets of small samples were prepared for repeat comparisons. The catalysts were then dried overnight at 120 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h to obtain the monolithic catalyst, which was denoted as Pt/Ce and Pt/LA, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained by an AXIS Ultra DLD (Kratos) to analyze the surface elemental composition. Correction was performed by referring to the characteristic binding energy (BE) of C 1 s at 284.6 eV. In order to obtain the state of O on the catalyst under the reaction conditions, the pretreatment of the catalysts for XPS measurements was the same as the catalytic reactions, namely, the catalyst was pre-activated in the reaction gas at 500 °C for 1 h. The reduction characteristics of the catalysts were evaluated by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Before the reduction process, the powder samples were pretreated in N2 (25 mL/min) at 450 °C for 1 h and then cooled to room temperature. After that, a mixture of H2 (5 vol.% H2, 20 mL/min) was passed through, and then the temperature was raised at a constant rate of 10 °C/min. Meanwhile the H2 consumption was detected using a TCD. Oxygen temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) evaluated the oxygen desorption ability of the catalysts. The treatment procedure was as follows: the sample was pretreated in He (25 mL/min) at 450 °C for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature. Then, the sample was adsorbed by O2 (5 vol.% O2/N2, 20 mL/min) for 60 min. After the adsorption, the sample was purged with He (30 mL min-1) to flatten the baseline, and finally warmed up to 450 °C at 10 °C/min under the atmosphere of He (30 mL/min) to obtain the corresponding spectra. In-situ DRIFTS spectra of CH4 NOCOO2 was used record the characteristic vibrations of intermediate species of a sample under reaction gas flow conditions by a Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. The crucible containing the samples was loaded into the reaction cell and the sample was raised from room temperature to 500 °C in a stream of N2 gas. At this temperature, the samples were kept in the gas flow of a mixture of CH4, NO, CO, O2 and N2 for 1 h for activation, and then lowered to below 300 °C in a stream of N2 gas and background was collected. After acquiring the background value, a gas of CH4, NO, CO, O2, and N2 was introduced, and the samples were warmed up to 550 °C (heating rate=5 °C/min) in reaction mixture. The spectra were recorded every 20 °C in the range of 1000–4000 cm-1 with 64 scans in Kubelka-Munk units. The infrared spectra of NO adsorption were also recorded with a Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. Firstly, the samples were pretreated by being exposed to a flow of N2 at 450 °C for 30 min and then background was collected at 30 °C. After acquiring the background value, the samples were exposed to 2 vol.% NO/N2 (30 mL/min) at 30 °C for 30 min until saturation coverage. In N2 flow, while 64 scans were performed every 5 min in the spectra of 1000–4000 cm-1 to collect infrared spectra. In-situ DRIFTS spectra of NOCH4 reactions recorded the characteristic vibrations of intermediate species of a sample under reaction gas flow conditions by a Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. After acquiring the background value, a gas stream of 3 vol.% NO/N2 and 3 vol.% CH4/N2 was introduced, after which the samples were then started to warm up to 550 °C at an elevated temperature rate of 5 °C/min, and the spectra were collected at different temperature points during the ramp-up. In-situ DRIFTS spectra of NOCO reactions recorded the characteristic vibrations of intermediate species of a sample under reaction gas flow conditions by a Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. After acquiring the background value, a gas stream of 3 vol.% NO/N2 and 2 vol.% CO/N2 was introduced, after which the samples were then started to warm up to 550 °C at an elevated temperature rate of 5 °C/min, and the spectra were collected at different temperature points during the ramp-up. 2.2 Catalyst performance evaluation The formation of NH3 and N2O in the exhaust gas of a stoichiometric natural gas vehicles was tested with a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. Bed temperature and reaction gas temperature are measured with type K thermocouples. The total gas flow rate was controlled by mass flow controllers to 1.84 L/min, corresponding to a GHSV of 50,400 h-1. The λ value is calculated according to the following formula (1) [21]. (1) λ = 2 [ O 2 ] + 2 [ C O 2 ] + [ CO ] + [ NO ] + [ H 2 O ] 2 [ C O 2 ] + 2 [ CO ] + 4 [ C H 4 ] + [ H 2 O ] The gas composition close to real exhaust composition at the stoichiometry (λ=1) is 1000 ppm CH4, 5000 ppm CO, 930 ppm NO, 4035 ppm O2, 5 vol.% H2O, 10 vol.% CO2 and the residual N2. Before the test, the monolithic catalyst was pretreated by being exposed to a flow of reaction gas at 500 °C for 1 h. The pre-treated monolithic catalysts were cooled to 150 °C in flowing N2. Thereafter, increase the temperature of the catalyst from 150 °C to 550 °C (5 °C/min). Meanwhile, the outlet concentration of the reaction gas was analyzed by Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (Antaris IGS, Thermos Fisher Science, America). Calculate the conversion of reactant species i (Xi) by the equation: (2) X i = 100 % · ( C i , inlet − C i , outlet ) C i , inlet where C i (inlet) represents the inlet gas volume concentration, C i (outlet) represents the outlet gas volume concentration and i represents the i th gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Different formation profiles of NH3 and N2O over Pt/Ce and Pt/La catalysts The formation concentrations of NH3, N2O as well as the conversion profiles of CH4, CO and NO with temperature have been depicted in Fig. 1 . Obviously, as shown in Fig. 1(a), much higher concentration of NH3 has been formed over Pt/Ce (16,498 ppm) than Pt/Al (9757 ppm). Moreover, Pt/Ce and Pt/LA exhibit different profiles of NH3 and N2O formation in terms of concentration and formation temperature. For Pt/LA, the formation of NH3 could be detected in the range of about 150–250 °C and 430–550 °C, with a peak value of 100 ppm and 110 ppm, respectively (Fig. 1(b)). And the cumulative concentration of NH3 formation at about 430–550 °C (6411 ppm) is about 1.9 times as much as that at about 150–250 °C (3346 ppm). Differently, although negligible NH3 has been detected in the low temperature, obvious concentration increase of NH3 has been detected from 380 °C for Pt/Ce catalyst, the maximum of which is about 200 ppm (Fig. 1(b)). As shown in Fig. 1(e) and (f), in the range of about 150–250 °C, deep conversion increase of CO and NO has been detected over Pt/LA, while CH4 hasn't been activated and purified. When the temperature increases to above 380 °C, the full conversion of CO has reached, the conversions of CH4 and NO over both Pt/LA and Pt/Ce have gradually increased, the trend of which is coincidence with the concentration of NH3. As a result, it was hypothesized that the formation of NH3 is related to the CO+NO+H2O reaction at about 150–250 °C and CH4+NO+H2O at higher temperatures. For N2O (Fig. 1(c)), Pt/LA with a highest peak value of 208 ppm exhibit a much higher concentration than Pt/Ce with 47 ppm. Moreover, the formation trend of N2O over Pt/LA was the same as that of NO and CO conversion, especially at about 150–250 °C, indicating that the formation N2O may be closely related to the reduction of NO by CO. In order to investigate the formation pathways of NH3 and N2O, the single reactions with different components over Pt/Ce and Pt/La have been carried out, the results of which have been depicted in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 . It could be found that NH3 would be formed in the reaction atmosphere consisting H2O and/or CH4 with NO (Fig. 2(a) and Fig. 3(a)). By a careful comparison, it is interesting that the profile of CH4 conversion and NH3 formation in the singer reaction of CH4+NO+CO+O2 is almost identical with that in the overall reaction (Fig. 2(b)), which indicates that the presence of H2O plays little effects in NH3 formation. Then it is reasonable to infer that the NH3 is mainly formed in CH4+NO+CO+O2 over Pt/Ce. For Pt/LA (Fig. 3), the rapid conversion of CH4 for the total reaction begins at 400 °C accompanied by the rapid conversion of NO, indicating that the conversion of NO at high temperatures (>400 °C) is most predominantly by the reduction of NO from CH4 (Fig. 3(b)). Combined with the fact that only NH3 is formed at high temperatures (Fig. 3(a)), it is therefore reasonable to infer that the NH3 is mainly formed in the reduction of NO by CH4 on Pt/LA. The formation profiles of N2O on Pt/Ce and Pt/LA catalysts with different component reactions are shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 . It can be seen that N2O can be formed in the reaction that consists CH4 and/or CO with NO, with be dominating in the reduction NO by CO. Specifically, the formation of N2O was higher for the CO+NO reaction compared to the CH4+NO reaction, and the formation of N2O for the reaction of CH4+CO+NO was similar to that of CO+NO (Fig. 4(a)). Namely, the presence of CH4 did not affect the formation of N2O on the Pt/Ce catalysts, indicating that the Pt/Ce catalysts formed N2O mainly from the reaction between CO and NO. Furthermore, at about 150–380 °C, the addition of H2O leads to a lower formation concentration of N2O in the total reaction of Pt/Ce compared to the high N2O formation in the reaction of CH4+NO+CO+O2, which is similar to that of the CH4+NO+CO+H2O reaction, and then it is reasonable to infer that the N2O is mainly formed in CH4+NO+CO+H2O over Pt/Ce. Fig. 4(b) shows that the conversion of NO for the total reaction is substantially lower at 150–350 °C compared to the reaction CH4+NO+CO+O2, suggesting that the addition of H2O promotes the water gas shift reaction leading to a lower amount of CO for the reduction of NO, which in turn leads to the formation of less N2O. For Pt/LA, as shown in Fig. 5, by a careful comparison, it is interesting that the conversion profile of CO and NO in the singer reaction of CH4+NO+CO+O2 at about 150–350 °C is almost identical with that in the overall reaction (Fig. 5(b) and (c)). The formation concentration of N2O and the conversion of NO for the total reaction of the Pt/LA at about 150–400 °C were similar to that of the reaction CH4+NO+CO+O2 (Fig. 5(a)), which indicates that the presence of H2O plays little effects in N2O formation. Therefore, it is reasonable to infer that N2O is mainly formed in the reaction CH4+NO+CO+O2 on Pt/LA. The total reaction showed that the cumulative formation concentration of N2O on the Pt/LA catalyst was about 4.2 times higher than that of Pt/Ce. In order to reveal the differences in the formation of NH3 and N2O for the two catalysts, the kinetics of NH3 and N2O formation were calculated for CH4+CO+NO+O2, CH4+CO+NO+H2O and the total reaction, respectively. The results in Fig. S4 show that the excellent redox properties and higher reactive oxygen species preferentially promote the reaction of H2O and O2 with CO, which in turn weakens the reaction of CO reduction by NO to form N2O at low temperatures. The reduction of NO with CH4 to form NH3 is enhanced at high temperatures. In order to verify the above conjecture, FTIR spectroscopy was utilized to collect spectral in formation related to the catalyst structure and active intermediates. The nature, thermal stability and reactivity of the surface products formed by the adsorption of CH4 NOCOO2 on the catalyst were investigated by in situ FTIR spectroscopy. Fig. 6 shows the interaction of CH4 NOCOO2 with Pt/Ce and Pt/LA catalysts under stoichiometric conditions during a gradual warming at 300 °C. Fig. 6(a) and Fig. 6(d) shows that a strong overlapping spectral bands attributed to NCO* and N2O were observed at 2240 cm-1 only for Pt/LA catalysts at about 300–440 °C[22], and this characteristic peak shows a tendency to increases and then decreases. Combined the results of N2O and NH3 formation over Pt/LA catalysts at about 300–400 °C (Fig. 1(a) and (b)), it was found that only N2O was formed at this temperature, indicating that this band is related to the formation of N2O. The overlapping peaks of Pt/Ce catalyst (Fig. 6(a)) concerning NCO* and N2O at this temperature are weak or even close to none, which proves that less N2O is formed on this catalyst, consistent with the results of active N2O formation. Fig. 6(a) shows that with increasing temperature (460–550 °C), bands attributed to NCO* was observed at 2162 cm-1 for Pt/Ce catalysts and a band of C = O adsorbed on Pt was observed at 2042 cm-1 [23]. The band observed for Pt/LA at 2240 cm-1 was attributed to NCO*. Specifically, the characteristic peaks attributed to NCO* species for the Pt/Ce catalyst gradually increased with increasing temperature, while the characteristic peaks attributed to NCO* species for Pt/LA showed an increase and then a decrease at about 380–550 °C, and the intensity of the characteristic peaks of NCO* on the two catalysts at this temperature is Pt/Ce>Pt/LA. Combining the formation concentrations of NH3 and N2O on the two catalysts (Fig. 1(a) and (b)), it was found that only NH3 was formed at high temperatures (about 380–550 °C) and the formation of NH3 on Pt/Ce was greater than that on Pt/LA at high temperatures, which was the same as the trend of the peak intensities of the NCO* species, and it can be hypothesized that the formation of NH3 was mainly related to the NCO* species. It is consistent with the results of that isocyanate species, as intermediates in the reaction of NO with CH4 or CO, is precursors for the formation of N2, NH3 and N2O, under the conditions of CO/CH4 NOO2 mixtures[24]. Where NH3 is formed by hydrolysis of NCO* species bound to the support in the presence of water[3]. As shown in Fig. 6(c), two same peaks at 2162 cm-1 and 2042 com-1, referring to NCO* and C = O adsorbed on Pt, have been detected on Pt/Ce in the atmosphere of CH4 NO and CH4 NOCOO2 in the nearly consistent temperature range of about 400–550 °C. In addition, the shoulder peak at 2042 cm-1 of Pt/Ce decreases in intensity with temperature from about 400 to 550 °C and was gradually replaced by gaseous adsorption of CO on Pt[25] at 1980 cm-1. This is due to the formation of CO from the reduction of NO by CH4 activated by adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface. For Pt/LA, different FTIR spectra have been detected in the flow of CH4 NO and CH4 NOCOO2. In detail, as shown in Fig. 6(d), neither peaks with -CN nor that referring to NCO* have been detected in Pt/LA in low-temperature region, while the bands of -CN species located at 2125 cm-1 become quite intense after 440 °C. The formation of NCO* species in the CH4 NOCOO2 reaction on Pt/LA at high temperature to the oxidation of -CN species [26]. This is due to the lack of oxygen, which leads to the formation of -CN from the reduction of NO by CH4 and the direct formation of NCO* intermediate species from the reduction of NO by CH4 in the CH4 NOCOO2 reaction in the presence of O2. However, as shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. 6(b), the formation of N2O over Pt/LA in low-temperature region (about 300–440 °C) is also associated with the NCO*, then to further explore the reaction that produce NCO* in this temperature range, the CONO spectra has also been characterized in Fig. 6(e) and (f). The overlapping band of NCO* and N2O was only observed at 2240 cm-1 for Pt/LA catalysts at about 300–400 °C. The results show that the overlapping bands of NCO* with N2O in this temperature range are formed by the reaction of NO+CO, which is mainly related to the formation of N2O. 3.2 Reasons affecting the difference in the formation amount of NH3 and N2O The above results suggest that the surface reactive oxygen species content influences the formation of NCO*. Therefore, we employed a combination of H2-TPR, O2-TPD and XPS of O1s measurements to quantify the surface oxygen species of the catalysts. The redox capacities of Pt/Ce and Pt/LA catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 (a). The strong reduction peak of α was attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed PtOx species, and the shoulder peak of β for Pt/Ce catalysts corresponds to the reduction of interacting CeO2 and PtOx[27,28]. The weak reduction peak of α for the Pt/LA catalyst was attributed to the reduction of PtOx species, and the peak of β corresponded to the weak reduction of adsorbed oxygen species as well as surface oxygen species on Al2O3 that is in contact with Pt particles[29]. By careful comparison, it was found that the reduction peaks of the Pt/Ce catalysts were much stronger than those of Pt/LA, indicating that the Pt/Ce catalyst surface has abundant reducible substances and surface adsorbed oxygen species, which is favorable for improving the catalytic activity. The oxygen desorption capacities of Pt/Ce and Pt/LA catalysts are shown in Fig. 7(b). The oxygen desorption peak at 80–200 °C of α is attributed to adsorbed oxygen species, and the oxygen desorption peak at 200–400 °C of β is attributed to desorption of lattice oxygen[30]. Surface-adsorbed oxygen species are more active than lattice oxygen species, implying that a large number of surface-adsorbed oxygen species contribute to rapid redox reactions[31,32]. The intensity of oxygen desorption peaks of Pt/Ce catalysts was significantly stronger than that of Pt/LA, indicating that Pt/Ce has more reactive oxygen species. O 1 s XPS spectra revealed the surface oxygen state and the results are shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d). The α peak at 529–530.4 eV was attributed to the lattice oxygen (Olat) bonded to the metal cation. The β peak at 530.7–531.7 eV was attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads)[31,33,34], the content of which affects the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the compound. In general, the concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen was consistent with the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the surface[32]. Consequently, the ratio of Oads/Oall in XPS is determined by dividing the surface adsorbed oxygen peaks by the total peak area of O 1 s, and the results are shown in Fig. 7(d). The content order of Oads is Pt/Ce>Pt/LA, as shown by the H2-TPR and O2-TPD results. More importantly, Oads species have high mobility and contribute to the reaction between CO with H2O and O2[35]. The adsorption state of NO on the catalyst surface is influenced by the content of surface adsorbed oxygen species. In order to study the adsorption state of NO over the catalysts, the FTIR study of NO adsorption over Pt/Ce and Pt/LA catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . There were significant differences in the NO adsorption capacity of the catalysts with different supports, and the Pt/Ce catalysts were more capable of adsorbing NO compared to the Pt/LA catalysts. Specifically, NO adsorption on Pt/Ce at 1215 cm-1, 1366 cm-1, 1492 cm-1, 1529 cm-1, and 1592 cm-1 were attributed to nitrate[36,37], and nitrite bands were observed at 1243 cm-1 and 1561 cm-1[38]. The distinct negative peaks occurring at 1350–1500 cm-1 were attributed to nitrate adsorption peaks[39]. Apparently, NO is mainly dominated by adsorbed nitrite and nitrate species on Pt/Ce catalysts. NO adsorption on the Pt/LA catalyst at 1141–1355 cm-1 and 1709 cm-1 were attributed to nitrite species[40], that at 1768 cm-1 correspond to NO adsorbed on Pt0, respectively[41]. Meanwhile, adsorption bands corresponding to nitrate were observed at 1549 cm-1 and 1612 cm-1[42]. The nitrite band was significantly stronger than the nitrate band, and the results indicated that NO was mainly adsorbed as nitrite on the Pt/LA catalyst. The above two catalysts showed a gradual enhancement of the nitrate spectral bands with increasing adsorption time during NO adsorption. This growth of the nitrate band means that one or more NOx species, such as nitrite, was converted to nitrate. When only NO was adsorbed, the most likely pathway for the formation of nitrate species is the oxidation of nitrite: nitrite + O*→ NO3 -. In the absence of gas-phase oxygen, these oxidizations involve adsorption of oxygen on the surface of the catalyst. That is, the Pt site can readily adsorb NO, which spills onto the support surface to first form adsorbed nitrite and then is gradually oxidized to nitrate by surface adsorbed oxygen (Reactions 3 and 5). Alternatively, NO is oxidized to NO2 on PtOx, which then reacts with adsorbed oxygen on the surface of the support to form nitrite and nitrate (Reactions 4 and 5). Comparison of the NO adsorbed species for the two catalysts revealed that the Pt/Ce catalyst has the highest amount of nitrate, followed by Pt/LA. Combined with the O 1S spectra of XPS, it was concluded that the amount of nitrate species was related to the amount of oxygen adsorbed on the surface, and the more oxygen adsorbed on the surface, the higher the amount of nitrate species. The results indicate that strong redox supports readily oxidize adsorbed NO to nitrate species. (3) NO+M+-O*→M+-NO2 - (4) NO2+M-□→M+-NO2 - (5) M+-NO2 -+M+-O*→M+-NO3 -+M-□ where □ represents an oxygen vacancy and O* is the surface adsorbed oxygen of the catalyst. 3.3 Discussions In summary, Pt/Ce catalysts have strong redox properties and high extractable oxygen content. The results of CH4 NO FTIR showed that only NCO* specie is observed for Pt/Ce catalysts, and only -CN specie is observed for Pt/LA catalysts at high temperatures, where NCO* can be oxidized from -CN. This is due to the fact that the extractable oxygen content in the Pt/Ce catalyst is higher than that of Pt/LA, resulting in the direct formation of NCO* as a reaction intermediate for the reduction of NO by CH4, which forms NH3. Therefore, stronger redox properties and higher extractable oxygen content can promote NH3 formation. As far as the formation of N2O is concerned, the above results indicate that N2O is formed by the reduction of NO by CO to form NCO* intermediate species. Adsorbed NCO* species can react with NO or NO2 to form N2O[43]. The O2-TPD and O1s results indicate that the Pt/Ce catalysts have high extractable oxygen content and strong oxygen transport properties, and they have a certain promotion effect on the reaction between CO with H2O and O2. The lower formation concentration of N2O (∼47 ppm) for the Pt/Ce catalysts was attributed to the excellent oxygen transport properties of the Pt/Ce catalysts that preferentially promoted the water vapor shift reaction, resulting in a weaker CO reduction of NO and the lesser formation of N2O. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the effects of catalysts with different support properties on the formation of NH3 and N2O were investigated. It was found that the Pt/Ce catalysts have strong redox properties and high extractable oxygen content. The activity results indicate that the cumulative formation concentration of NH3 for the Pt/Ce catalyst was about 1.7 times higher than that of Pt/LA, about 16,498 ppm. The cumulative formation concentration of N2O on the Pt/LA catalyst was about 4.2 times higher than that of Pt/Ce, about 21,383 ppm. FTIR results indicate that NCO* species are observed at high temperatures, which are formed by the reaction of oxygen-activated CH4 with NO, and upon hydrolysis to form NH3. Combined with the single reaction results suggest that NH3 can be formed by the reaction CH4+NO+CO+O2. The Pt/Ce catalyst promotes the formation of NCO* at high temperatures from by the reaction of oxygen-activated CH4 with NO, which in turn hydrolyses to form large amounts of NH3. N2O is formed by the reduction of NO by CO. Specifically, the Pt/Ce catalyst preferentially activates the reaction between CO with H2O and O2 at low temperatures due to its strong redox properties and high extractable oxygen content, leading to a weaker competition for the reduction of NO reaction by CO at low temperatures, which in turn leads to less formation of N2O. Namely, on the Pt/Ce catalyst, N2O is mainly formed by the reaction of CO2+CH4+NO+CO+H2O. On the other hand, N2O is mainly formed by CO2+CH4+NO+CO+O2 reaction on Pt/LA catalyst due to the lack of extractable oxygen. This work deepens the understanding of how redox properties affect the formation pathways of NH3 and N2O over Pt-based ternary catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The formation of new pollutants NH3 and N2O during the conversion of nitrogen oxides by three-way catalysts (TWC) has a significant impact on the environment and human health, so it is necessary to understand their formation pathways. The redox performance of the support and the surface active oxygen species affect the catalytic reaction performance and selectivity. In this work, the effect of CeO2 (Ce) and γ-Al2O3 (La-Al2O3, LA), the two kinds of widely used supports for Pt-based TWC on the formation pathways of NH3 and N2O was investigated due to the different support redox properties and surface reactive oxygen species affecting the reactant reaction properties. NH3 and N2O are formed by the reaction of oxygen activated CH4 or CO with NO, respectively. The cumulative formation concentration of NH3 and N2O over Pt/Ce are about 1.7 and 0.24 times more than that of Pt/LA, about 16,498 and 5059 ppm, respectively. The Pt/Ce catalyst has strong redox properties and high extractable oxygen content. At high temperatures, it promotes the formation of NCO* from the reduction of NO by oxygen-activated CH4, which in turn hydrolyzes to form a large amount of NH3. At low temperatures, it preferentially activates the reaction between CO with H2O and O2, which leads to a weaker competition for the reduction of NO by CO, which in turn leads to the formation of a smaller amount of N2O. This study provides new ideas for the formation mechanism of NH3 and N2O in stoichiometric natural gas vehicles (NGVs).
